facts.text: The respondent (assessee) purchased Silver Cloud Estate in 1950

holdings.text: the payment of interest on the amount borrowed for the purchase of the plantation when the whole transaction of purchase and the working of the plantation is viewed as an integrated whole, is so closely related to the plantation that the expenditure can be said to be laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the plantation.

Ile assessee had bought the plantation for working it as a plantation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide scope of 'purpose of the plantation/business' per Malayalam Plantations includes preservation/protection; owner-worker inseparable; integrated purchase-operation; commercial accounting deducts such interest for true net income.

precedents.citation: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, 1955 1 S.C.R. 972

anchor.surface_text: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax,   in the following words Outlay is deemed to be capital when it is made for the initiation of a business, for extension of  1  1955 1 S.C.R. 972

precedents.case_name: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Broad principles to determine whether an expenditure is revenue or capital expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: Outlay is deemed to be capital when it is made for the initiation of a business, for extension of a business, or for a substantial replacement of equipment; Expenditure may be treated as properly attributable to capital when it is made not only once and for all, but with a view to bringing into existence an asset or an advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Granite City Steamship Company  1927  13 T.C. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Granite City Steamship Company  1927  13 T.C. 1 and City of London Contract Corporation v. Styles  1887  2 T.C. 239. Expenditure may be treated as properly attributable to capital when it is made

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Granite City Steamship Company
precedents.cited_proposition: Outlay deemed capital for substantial replacement of equipment

precedents.citation: City of London Contract Corporation v. Styles  1887  2 T.C. 239

anchor.surface_text: City of London Contract Corporation v. Styles  1887  2 T.C. 239. Expenditure may be treated as properly attributable to capital when it is made number only once and for all, but with a view to bringing into existence an asset or an advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade vide Viscount Cave

precedents.case_name: City of London Contract Corporation v. Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Outlay deemed capital for initiation or extension of business

precedents.citation: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.,  1926  10 T.C. 155

anchor.surface_text: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.,  1926  10 T.C. 155. If what is got rid of by a lump sum payment is an annual business expense chargeable against revenue, the lump sum payment should equally be regarded as a business expense

precedents.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Expenditure for enduring benefit is capital

precedents.citation: S. Kuppuswami v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras , I.L.R.  1954  Mad. 977

anchor.surface_text: In S. Kuppuswami v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras  , the assessee was held to have acquired the goodwill by paying a certain share of profits. This was held to be capital expenditure.

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment of share of profits to acquire goodwill is capital expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: The assessee was held to have acquired the goodwill by paying a certain share of profits. This was held to be capital expenditure.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. Siddareddy Venkatasubba Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: Money expended for acquisition of mining rights is capital expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: The High Court held the money expended for the acquisition of mining rights to be capital expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: In The European Investment Trust Company Limited v. Jackson   the Court of Appeal was companycerned with the inter- pretation of Rules 3 of the Rules applicable to Cases I and 11 of Schedule D of the Income Tax Act, 1918

precedents.case_name: European Investment Trust Company Limited v. Jackson
precedents.cited_proposition: Interpretation of rules prohibiting deduction of interest payable out of profits

precedents.citation: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles  3 T.C. 185

anchor.surface_text: Lord Herschall observed in Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles 2  as follows I think the fourth rule was primarily designed to meet such a case as that in which a trader had companytracted to make an annual payment out of his profits

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule designed for annual payments out of profits like to former partner or loan
precedents.cited_holding: I think the fourth rule was primarily designed to meet such a case as that in which a trader had contracted to make an annual payment out of his profits, as for example, when he had agreed to make such a payment to a former partner or to a person who had made a loan on the terms of receiving such a payment.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of IncomeTax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantation Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, after reviewing English and Indian cases, summarised the position in Commissioner of IncomeTax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantation Ltd.   as follows The aforesaid discussion leads to the following result The expression for the purpose of the business is wider in scope than the expression for the purpose of companying profits.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Kerala v. Malayalam Plantation Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'for the purpose of the business'
precedents.cited_holding: The expression for the purpose of the business is wider in scope than the expression for the purpose of earning profits. Its range is wide... The purpose shall be for the purpose of the business, that is to say, the expenditure incurred shall be for carrying on of the business and the assessee shall incur it in his capacity as a person carrying on the business.

precedents.citation: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal   C.A. Nos. 384 and 385165 decided on April 10, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In Eastern Investments Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal   this Court held that interest on debentures issued by an investment Company was to be allowed as business expen- diture under s. 12  2  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Interest on debentures issued by investment company for its investments is deductible as business expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: Interest on debentures issued by an investment company was to be allowed as business expenditure under s. 12(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act.

precedents.citation: Dharamvir Dhir v. The Commissioner of Income Tax  , 1961 3 S.C.R. 359

anchor.surface_text: In Dharamvir Dhir v. The Commissioner of Income Tax  2 , this Court held that a payment of 11/16 of the net profits of the assessees business was an expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purposes of the business as the assessee had arranged financing of the business on the best terms that he companyld manage.

precedents.case_name: Dharamvir Dhir v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment of share of net profits for financing business is deductible expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: A payment of 11/16 of the net profits of the assessee's business was an expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purposes of the business as the assessee had arranged financing of the business on the best terms that he could manage.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay v. Jagannath Kissonlal
precedents.cited_proposition: Deduction allowed for amount paid to bank on joint promissory note
precedents.cited_holding: This Court upheld the claim of the assessee to deduct the amount it had to pay the bank on a joint promissory note.

precedents.citation: Metro Theatre Bombay Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

anchor.surface_text: The only case cited by Mr. Chetty, which has some resemblance to the present case is the decision of the Bombay High Court in Metro Theatre Bombay Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax  4  . But this case is distin- guishable for the interest claimed to be deducted, and which was disallowed, was in respect of the amount borrowed for acquiring land on 999 years lease, on which a cinema was subsequently built.

precedents.case_name: Metro Theatre Bombay Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Interest on borrowing for acquiring land on lease (before business commenced) not deductible
precedents.cited_holding: Interest claimed to be deducted, and which was disallowed, was in respect of the amount borrowed for acquiring land on 999 years lease, on which a cinema was subsequently built. There was no immediate connection between the interest paid and the cinema business.

directions: assessment to be revised allowing full deduction
